0: Media caption Donald Trump speaking at a rally in Florida NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has insisted that his campaign is united despite reports of deep divisions in the party after he made a series of missteps. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Speaking at a rally in Florida, Mr Trump said the campaign was "doing really well". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR US media outlets said it was in turmoil after Mr Trump repeatedly attacked parents of a fallen US soldier. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Staffers told CNN that they "feel like they are wasting their time". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I just want to tell you the campaign is doing really well," the nominee said in Daytona Beach. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "It's never been so well united... I would say right now it's the best in terms of being united that it's been since we began." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Earlier Mr Trump's campaign chairman Paul Manafort blamed reports of disunity on Mr Trump's opponent, Democrat Hillary Clinton. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "This is another Clinton narrative that she put out there and the media is picking up on," he said. "Mr Trump has appeared this week at crowds that are overflowing into the street." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Political calculus - analysis by Anthony Zurcher, BBC News North America reporter NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright AP Image caption Mr Manafort called reports of campaign turmoil "a Clinton narrative" NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Donald Trump rollercoaster is picking up speed. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Thanks to a week with enough controversies for an entire election season, Republicans are flooding the media with reports of campaign chaos and an impending mass defection from their nominee if things don't turn around quickly. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Behind all these stories of political discord, however, is the simple fact that while insider establishment operatives may be looking for the exits, Republican officeholders who must eventually answer to the 13 million Trump primary voters have yet to break ranks. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Things will have to get very bad - much worse than they are now - to result in the sort of doomsday scenarios currently being pondered. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It is a simple political calculus. The key, as always, is in the polls and public sentiment. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR If Mr Trump appears to have a reasonable chance to win in November, he will persevere, as he has all year. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR If his poll numbers crash, and Republican politicians start worrying more about losing their own races in November than alienating their party's base, the Trump-coaster could careen off the rails at last. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Going against Mr Trump is still a risky bet. And when it comes to preserving their jobs, politicians are all about minimising risk. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Hillary's email problem: read more from Anthony NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The New York billionaire has been sharply criticised for his attacks on the bereaved parents of a US Muslim soldier killed in Iraq. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR His ongoing war of words with Khizr and Ghazala Khan - the parents of Capt Humayun Khan - has intensified rifts within the Republican Party. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NBC News reported that senior Republicans plan to stage an "intervention" to get the campaign back on message, stressing issues such as jobs and trade deals. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The effort will be led, according to NBC, by Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus and Trump allies former House Speaker Newt Gingrich and former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I think some of what Trump has done is very self-destructive," Mr Gingrich told Fox Business Network on Wednesday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Three prominent Republicans - including New York Congressman Richard Hanna - have said this week that they would vote for Mrs Clinton, saying Mr Trump was unfit to serve as president. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Many Republicans opposed to Mr Trump have stopped short of supporting Mrs Clinton, saying they would vote for a third candidate instead. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright AP Image caption Clint Eastwood said Mr Trump was an enemy of political correctness NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR One person who did say he would back Mr Trump on Wednesday was Hollywood actor and director Clint Eastwood. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR While stopping short of endorsing Mr Trump, Eastwood said he would vote for him. "I can understand where he's coming from, but I don't always agree with it," he told Esquire magazine. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Eastwood, 86, also said Mr Trump was an enemy of political correctness, adding: "We see people accusing people of being racist and all kinds of stuff. When I grew up, those things weren't called racist."
